qas.question: Which philosophy branch is concerned with issues surrounding ontology?
The philosophy of space and time was inspired by what kind of philosophy?
The  philosophy of space and time focuses on whether or not time and space exist independently of what?
The  philosophy of space and time focuses what kind of flow within time?
What was the study of space and time inspired by?
What does not change over time?
The flow within what is multidirectional?

context: <a0_0><b4_0>Philosophy of space and time<b4_0/><a0_0/> is the branch of philosophy concerned with the issues surrounding the ontology, epistemology, and character of space and time. While such ideas have been central to philosophy from its inception, the philosophy of space and time was both an inspiration for and a central aspect of <a1_0>early <b5_0>analytic philosophy<b5_0/><a1_0/>. The subject focuses on a number of basic issues, including whether or not time and space exist independently of <a2_0>the mind<a2_0/>, whether they exist independently of one another, what accounts for <b7_0>time<b7_0/>'s apparently <a3_0>unidirectional<a3_0/> flow, whether times other than the present moment exist, and questions about the nature of identity (particularly <b6_0>the nature of identity<b6_0/> over time).
